subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Correspondence
msgSnippet: Sid: To see the Quikscript you have to log on to Read_Alphabet.  Go to font section and download the Jerome.ttf font.  Keep track of where you download it on
messageBody:
Sid:
 
To see the Quikscript you have to log on to Read_Alphabet.  Go to font section and download the Jerome.ttf font.  Keep track of where you download it on your computer.  Once the download is complete, use Windows explorer to go to the spot where the download is saved.  Copy the file (Jerome.ttf) and paste it in your windows fonts directory (folder).
 
When this is done successfully, your list of fonts will include Jerome.  It will be available to your word processor or to Wordpad.  When I was using Windows 98, I occasionally had a little problem getting it to work with my browser.  The Quikscript characters are set up the same as the Shavian fonts are on the keyboard.  To be able to type messages in Quikscript, you have to learn the position of the letters. 
 
We are currently discussing a remapping of the Quikscript character locations on the keyboard to make them easier, i.e. more logical, to learn.  In addition to the Quikscript version of the Shavian characters, Jerome also has the half-letters and alternate letters which Read added to Quikscript, plus the characters which Jon Zuck refers to as "ligatures" by which he mean the characters combining a vowel followed by an "r."
 
 
Paige
----- Original Message -----
From: Sidney Tanaban
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, February 22, 2002 2:20 PM
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Correspondence

Hi!
I am interested in corresponding but I have no idea what you guys are doing.  Could explain step by step what to do to see the Quikskript?  And how do you write in Quikskript on Internet?
Sid 


On Mon, 18 February 2002, "Ed Gaddy" wrote:
